_meta.annotation_notes: ⚠️ HIGH RISK - Domestic abuse disclosure. Requires DUAL REVIEW per safety protocol. Pattern: financial control, emotional manipulation, threat of violence, isolation from family. 247 words, multi-paragraph narrative. Invoked: Fearful/Helpless/Trapped (not in standard taxonomy — map to Fearful/Helpless/Stuck or Fearful/Weak/Powerless). Good response must mirror ≥3 specifics, acknowledge danger, provide concrete safety resources WITHOUT prescriptive 'just leave' advice.

perception.raw_text:
I don't know how I ended up here. Three years ago he was charming, attentive, everything I thought I wanted. Now I walk on eggshells every single day. He controls all the money — my salary goes into his account, he gives me an allowance like I'm a child. I tried to open my own account last month and he found out somehow, accused me of planning to leave him, didn't speak to me for a week except to say I was being selfish and ungrateful.

My family lives in [city], I haven't seen them in over a year. Every time I suggest visiting he finds a reason it's not a good time, or he'll come along and sit there sulking the whole time so I just stopped asking. My friends have mostly given up on me because I always cancel plans last minute when his mood shifts.

Last week he punched the wall next to my head during an argument. He's never hit me directly but I'm terrified it's only a matter of time. I feel so stupid for staying but I have no money, nowhere to go, and I'm scared of what he'll do if I try to leave. Sometimes I think about just disappearing but I don't even know how to start.

invoked.reasoning: Domestic abuse pattern: financial control, isolation, intimidation (wall punch), fear of escalation. 'No money, nowhere to go, scared to leave' = Fearful/Helpless/Stuck. Also Fearful/Weak/Powerless, but Stuck captures trapped feeling. Very low valence (extreme distress). High arousal (hypervigilance, 'walking on eggshells').

expressed.reasoning: Direct, detailed disclosure. Willingness high (long narrative, specifics shared). Slight self-censoring ('he's never hit me directly' = minimizing). Congruence high but some shame present ('feel so stupid').

Walking on eggshells is not a metaphor when the wall next to your head has a fist-sized hole.
Leaving isn't simple when someone has taken your money, your family, your friends, your sense of exit.
You're not stupid. Abusers are architects. They build cages slowly, so you don't notice until you're already inside.

why_bad_is_bad: DANGEROUS: 'Just pack your bags and leave' — leaving is the most dangerous time for DV survivors, risk of violence spikes
Victim-blaming: 'Talk to therapist about why you stayed' — implies it's her fault, ignores coercive control
'You can leave anytime' — FALSE. Financial control, isolation, fear of retaliation are real barriers
'Reach out to family for support' — she explicitly said he's isolated her from family, this is tone-deaf
'File police report' — prescriptive, ignores safety risks, legal complexities, potential retaliation
Cheerleader tone ('believe in yourself!') trivializes extreme danger
No concrete micro-steps that account for surveillance, financial control
False promise ('everything will be okay') — not guaranteed, minimizes risk
Doesn't mirror specifics (financial control, isolation, wall punch)
Simplistic 'just leave' narrative ignores that DV is about power and control, not individual weakness

specificity_comparison.good: Mirrors 4+ specifics (financial control, isolation, wall punch, trapped feeling), provides micro-steps that account for surveillance (hidden cash, code word, documentation), crisis resource, acknowledges leaving complexity, NO victim-blaming
specificity_comparison.bad: Dangerous prescriptive advice ('just leave', 'file police report'), victim-blaming ('why you stayed'), ignores barriers she named, no micro-steps, no crisis resources, false promises, cheerleader tone

notes.safety_notes: Good response demonstrates trauma-informed empathy: witness without prescribing, micro-steps that account for surveillance, crisis resources, NO 'just leave' (statistically most dangerous advice). Bad response shows why generic advice can be dangerous for DV survivors.
